Resource-Aware Hierarchical Federated Learning for Video Caching in Wireless Networks

Md Ferdous Pervej and Andreas F. Molisch

Abstract

Video caching can significantly improve backhaul traffic congestion by locally storing the popular content that users frequently request. A privacy-preserving method is desirable to learn how users’ demands change over time. As such, this paper proposes a novel resource-aware hierarchical federated learning (RawHFL) solution to predict users’ future content requests under the realistic assumptions that content requests are sporadic and users’ datasets can only be updated based on the requested content’s information. Considering a partial client participation case, we first derive the upper bound of the global gradient norm that depends on the clients’ local training rounds and the successful reception of their accumulated gradients over the wireless links. Under delay, energy and radio resource constraints, we then optimize client selection and their local rounds and central processing unit (CPU) frequencies to minimize a weighted utility function that facilitates RawHFL’s convergence in an energy-efficient way. Our simulation results show that the proposed solution significantly outperforms the considered baselines in terms of prediction accuracy and total energy expenditure.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, resource-aware hierarchical federated learning, resource optimization, video caching.

I Introduction

Video streaming is the dominant source of data traffic, and 333 out of 555 video views occur on wireless devices [1]. As such, content caching [2] can become an integral part of modern wireless networks since it can save the backhaul transmission bandwidth and reduce network congestion by ignoring repetitive extractions of the same few popular videos the users repeatedly request from the far-away cloud.

Two major design components of an efficient video caching platform are content placement and content delivery [3]. Knowing which content the users will request in the near future can crucially help the provider in the content placement phase. However, it is often challenging to predict content popularity as it changes rapidly. Besides, many users may have their individual preferences for specific types of content that are not necessarily globally popular. While machine learning (ML) may accurately predict content popularity or user-specific content demand, the need for immense number of data samples for training the ML model poses challenges in wireless video caching platforms.

A further challenge arises from requirements for privacy and/or protection of business secrets. The user equipment (UE) makes a content request using its serving base station (BS) to the content service provider (CSP) in wireless networks. On the one hand, the UE and the CSP do not reveal the exact content ID/information to the BS, the former because they want to protect their privacy, and the latter because CSP and the (wireless) internet service provider (ISP) operating the BS are often competitors. On the other hand, the spatial information of the UEs is only known to the ISPs, which does not want to convey it to the CSP. As such, privacy-preserving coordination among the UEs, ISPs and CSP is required. Therefore, distributed and privacy-preserving federated learning (FL) [4] is ideal for video caching in wireless networks.

Some existing literature [5, 6, 7, 8, 9] acknowledged the need for privacy protection and proposed FL-based solutions for content caching. In [5], Qiao et al. proposed a FL solution for content caching in resource-constrained wireless networks using two separate deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents to find a subset of clients and their local training rounds. Wang et al. also leveraged a similar strategy [6], where users and edge servers used two separate DRL agents to learn computation offloading and content placement strategies, respectively. Both [5] and [6] considered federated aggregation of the DRL agents. Jiang et al. used an offline individual content preference learning, followed by an adaptive context space partitioning and FL-based popularity prediction algorithm in [7]. Li et al. developed an attention-weighted FL algorithm for device-to-device wireless networks where they partition the UEs into groups based on mobility and social behaviors in [8]. Khanal et al. proposed a self-attention-based FL algorithm for content caching in vehicular networks where the moving self-driving cars, roadside units and macro BS work collaboratively to train the model in [9].

While the above studies recognized the privacy concern in content caching, the cooperation among the three entities, i.e., UE, BS and CSP, was not addressed. Besides, the above studies assumed that the client’s111We use the terms UE and client interchangeably throughout the paper. training dataset is readily available. In reality, a UE’s content requests are sporadic, and its dataset only contains the requested content’s information. Moreover, since practical networks have hierarchical architectures where the client only communicates with its immediate upper tier, i.e., the BS [10], a hierarchical federated learning (HFL) solution is needed.

Motivated by the above facts, we propose a novel resource-aware hierarchical federated learning (RawHFL) algorithm for predicting clients’ future content requests. We consider that UEs’ requests arrive based on their own requirements, and their datasets can only be updated with the requested content’s information. Incorporating the well-known system and data heterogeneity, we derive the convergence analysis that reveals that the global gradient norm depends on the successful reception of the clients’ trained accumulated gradients and their local training rounds. As such, we jointly optimize client selection and clients’ local training rounds and CPU cycles to minimize a weighted utility function that facilitates RawHFL’s convergence and minimizes energy expense under delay, energy and radio resource constraints. Our extensive simulation results validate that the proposed solution outperforms existing baselines in terms of test accuracy and energy expense.

II System Model

II-A Network Model

We consider a cache-enabled wireless network, consisting of distributed UEs, BSs and a CSP. Denote the UE set 𝒰={u}u=0U−1𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑢0𝑈1\mathcal{U}=\{u\}_{u=0}^{U-1} and the BS set by ℬ={b}b=0B−1ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑏0𝐵1\mathcal{B}=\{b\}_{b=0}^{B-1}. Besides, denote the UEs that are associated to BS b𝑏b by 𝒰bsubscript𝒰𝑏\mathcal{U}_{b} such that 𝒰=⋃b=0B−1𝒰b𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑏0𝐵1subscript𝒰𝑏\mathcal{U}=\bigcup_{b=0}^{B-1}\mathcal{U}_{b}. The system operates in discrete time slot t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\dots,T, where the duration between two slots is κ𝜅\kappa seconds. The CSP has a fixed content catalog, denoted by 𝒞={𝒞g}g=0G−1𝒞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑔𝑔0𝐺1\mathcal{C}=\{\mathcal{C}_{g}\}_{g=0}^{G-1}, where 𝒞g={cg}c=0C¯−1subscript𝒞𝑔superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑐𝑔𝑐0¯𝐶1\mathcal{C}_{g}=\{c_{g}\}_{c=0}^{\bar{C}-1} is the content set of genre g𝑔g. Besides, denote the total number of content in the catalog by C=C¯​G𝐶¯𝐶𝐺C=\bar{C}G. Each BS is equipped with an edge server (ES) that has a limited cache storage and computation capability, and is under the control of the CSP. Consequently, the BS has no information about what content is stored in the ES. To keep its operational information private, the CSP assigns temporal tag IDs to the original content ID that it shares with the BS. The mappings between the actual content IDs and the tagged IDs are only known to the CSP and the UEs. Moreover, the CSP can periodically change these mappings to prevent the BS from learning the actual content information. Note that since each BS is equipped with a distinct ES, we use the same notation b𝑏b to represent the ES of the bthsuperscript𝑏thb^{\mathrm{th}} BS for brevity.

The network has Z¯¯Z\bar{\mathrm{Z}} Hz bandwidth allocated for performing the FL task, which is further divided into 𝒵={z}z=0Z−1𝒵superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑧0𝑍1\mathcal{Z}=\{z\}_{z=0}^{Z-1} orthogonal physical resource blocks. The frequency reuse factor is 111, i.e., each BS utilizes the same pRB set. Besides, we assume that the BSs collaborate to find node associations and pRB allocations such that inter-cell interference is fully mitigated. A list of the important notations used in this paper is summarized in Table I.

This work assumes that each UE has a small initial historical raw dataset, denoted by 𝒟u,r0superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑢r0\mathcal{D}_{u,\mathrm{r}}^{0}. During slot t𝑡t, a UE may request a content from the CSP with probability pu,acsubscript𝑝𝑢acp_{u,\mathrm{ac}}, which can be chosen according to the UE’s activity level. where 𝐱​(1u,cgt)𝐱superscriptsubscript1𝑢subscript𝑐𝑔𝑡\mathbf{x}(\mathrm{1}_{u,c_{g}}^{t}) and 𝐲​(1u,cgt)𝐲superscriptsubscript1𝑢subscript𝑐𝑔𝑡\mathbf{y}(\mathrm{1}_{u,c_{g}}^{t}) are the feature and label vectors, respectively, for the requested content. As such, our dataset acquisition mimics the natural data sensing in real-world applications, where the dataset sizes are time-varying [11, 12].

Besides, each UE follows a popularity-preference tradeoff in its content request model. More specifically, the UEs have their own independent genre preferences. Denote UE u𝑢u’s preference for genre g𝑔g by pu,gsubscript𝑝𝑢𝑔p_{u,g} such that 0≤pu,g≤10subscript𝑝𝑢𝑔10\leq p_{u,g}\leq 1 and ∑g=0G−1pu,g=1superscriptsubscript𝑔0𝐺1subscript𝑝𝑢𝑔1\sum_{g=0}^{G-1}p_{u,g}=1. We model the genre preference using symmetric Dirichlet distribution Dir​(𝚼)Dir𝚼\mathrm{Dir}(\boldsymbol{\Upsilon}), where the 𝚼𝚼\boldsymbol{\Upsilon} is the concentration parameter that controls the skewness [13]. Initially, the UE requests the most popular content from the selected genre g𝑔g. For the subsequent request, it requests the most similar content222We consider each content’s distinctive feature set and calculate the cosine similarity of the content within the same genre. to the previously requested content in the same genre g𝑔g with probability υusubscript𝜐𝑢\upsilon_{u} and the most popular content of a different genre g′≠gsuperscript𝑔′𝑔g^{\prime}\neq g with probability (1−υu)1subscript𝜐𝑢(1-\upsilon_{u}).

While the UEs will not reveal their content preferences, they are eager to participate in the model training and share their predictions with the ES. III Resource-Aware Hierarchical Federated Learning: Algorithm and Convergence

III-A Resource-Aware Hierarchical Federated Learning Model

Similar to general HFL [14, 15, 10], in our proposed RawHFL, the clients, the ES and the central server perform local, edge and global rounds. The nodes in each tier perform their local training before sending their updated models to their respective upper levels. Besides, due to resource constraints, we consider that each ES selects only a subset of the clients to participate in model training. (6)

Note that due to the subset client selection, each ES minimizes fb​(𝐰|∪u∈𝒰¯bk,e𝒟u,proct)≔∑u∈𝒰¯bk,eαu​fu​(𝐰|𝒟u,proct)≔subscript𝑓𝑏conditional𝐰subscript𝑢superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑢proc𝑡subscript𝑢superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒subscript𝛼𝑢subscript𝑓𝑢conditional𝐰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑢proc𝑡f_{b}(\mathbf{w}|\cup_{u\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}}\mathcal{D}_{u,\mathrm{proc}}^{t})\coloneqq\sum\nolimits_{u\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}}\alpha_{u}f_{u}(\mathbf{w}|\mathcal{D}_{u,\mathrm{proc}}^{t}), where αu≔1/|𝒰¯bk,e|≔subscript𝛼𝑢1superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒\alpha_{u}\coloneqq 1/|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}|. During the edge aggregation time, each ES updates its edge model using the g~uk,esuperscriptsubscript~g𝑢𝑘𝑒\tilde{\mathrm{g}}_{u}^{k,e}’s from all of its selected clients as

𝐰bk,e+1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑏𝑘𝑒1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{b}^{k,e+1} =𝐰bk,e−η​∑u∈𝒰¯bk,eαu​[1u,sck,e/pu,sck,e]​g~uk,e,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑏𝑘𝑒𝜂subscript𝑢superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒subscript𝛼𝑢delimited-[]superscriptsubscript1𝑢sc𝑘𝑒superscriptsubscriptp𝑢sc𝑘𝑒superscriptsubscript~g𝑢𝑘𝑒\displaystyle=\mathbf{w}_{b}^{k,e}-\eta\sum\nolimits_{u\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}}\alpha_{u}\big{[}\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e}/\mathrm{p}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e}\big{]}\tilde{\mathrm{g}}_{u}^{k,e}, (14)

where 1u,sck,esuperscriptsubscript1𝑢sc𝑘𝑒\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e} is a binary indicator that defines whether g~uk,esuperscriptsubscript~g𝑢𝑘𝑒\tilde{\mathrm{g}}_{u}^{k,e} is received at the BS during the aggregation time and is defined as

1u,sck,esuperscriptsubscript1𝑢sc𝑘𝑒\displaystyle\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e} ={1,with probability ​pu,sck,e,0,otherwise,.absentcases1with probability superscriptsubscriptp𝑢sc𝑘𝑒0otherwise\displaystyle=\begin{cases}1,&\text{with probability }\mathrm{p}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e},\\ 0,&\text{otherwise},\end{cases}. Each BS then broadcasts their respective ES’ updated model to their selected clients, and the clients perform local training and offload back the accumulated gradients. This process repeats for E𝐸E edge rounds, after which the ESs send their updated models to the central server that aggregates the received edge models as

𝐰k+1=𝐰k−η​∑e=0E−1∑b=0B−1αb​∑u∈𝒰¯bk,eαu​[1u,sck,e/pu,sck,e]​g~uk,e.superscript𝐰𝑘1superscript𝐰𝑘𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑒0𝐸1superscriptsubscript𝑏0𝐵1subscript𝛼𝑏subscript𝑢superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒subscript𝛼𝑢delimited-[]superscriptsubscript1𝑢sc𝑘𝑒superscriptsubscriptp𝑢sc𝑘𝑒superscriptsubscript~g𝑢𝑘𝑒\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\mathbf{w}^{k+1}\!\!=\mathbf{w}^{k}\!\!-\eta\sum\nolimits_{e=0}^{E-1}\sum\nolimits_{b=0}^{B-1}\!\!\alpha_{b}\sum\nolimits_{u\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}}\alpha_{u}\big{[}\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e}/\mathrm{p}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e}\big{]}\tilde{\mathrm{g}}_{u}^{k,e}\!\!. (16)

Note that the global loss of RawHFL is f(𝐰k|∪b=0B−1∪u∈𝒰¯bk,e𝒟u,proct)≔∑b=0B−1αbfb(𝐰k|∪u∈𝒰¯bk,e𝒟u,proct)f(\mathbf{w}^{k}|\cup_{b=0}^{B-1}\cup_{u\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}}\mathcal{D}_{u,\mathrm{proc}}^{t})\coloneqq\sum\nolimits_{b=0}^{B-1}\alpha_{b}f_{b}\big{(}\mathbf{w}^{k}|\cup_{u\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}}\mathcal{D}_{u,\mathrm{proc}}^{t}\big{)}, which may differ from (3) if 𝒰bk,e⊂𝒰bsuperscriptsubscript𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒subscript𝒰𝑏\mathcal{U}_{b}^{k,e}\subset\mathcal{U}_{b}. The central server then sends this updated model to the ESs, who perform their edge rounds following the above process. Algorithm 1 summarizes these steps.

III-B Convergence of RawHFL

We make the following standard assumptions [14, 15, 10]

  1. 1.

    The loss functions are β𝛽\beta-smooth.

  2. 2.

    The mini-batch gradients are unbiased. The variance of the gradients is bounded, i.e., ‖g​(𝐰)−∇fu​(𝐰)‖2≤σ2superscriptnorm𝑔𝐰∇subscript𝑓𝑢𝐰2superscript𝜎2\|g(\mathbf{w})-\nabla f_{u}(\mathbf{w})\|^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}.

  3. 3.

    The stochastic gradients in different local epochs, client selection and accumulated gradient offloading in edge rounds are independent.

  4. 4.

    The divergence between the two interconnected tiers’ loss functions is bounded. For all u𝑢u, b𝑏b and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w},

    ∑u∈𝒰bαu​‖∇fu​(𝐰)−∇fb​(𝐰)‖2≤ϵ02,subscript𝑢subscript𝒰𝑏subscript𝛼𝑢superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑢𝐰∇subscript𝑓𝑏𝐰2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{b}}\alpha_{u}\|\nabla f_{u}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla f_{b}(\mathbf{w})\|^{2}\leq\epsilon_{0}^{2},
    ∑b=0B−1αb​‖∑u∈𝒰¯bk,eαu​∇f~u​(𝐰)−∑b′=0B−1αb′​∑u′∈𝒰¯b′k,eαu′​∇f~u′​(𝐰)‖2≤ϵ12,superscriptsubscript𝑏0𝐵1subscript𝛼𝑏superscriptnormsubscript𝑢superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒subscript𝛼𝑢∇subscript~𝑓𝑢𝐰superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑏′0𝐵1subscript𝛼superscript𝑏′subscriptsuperscript𝑢′superscriptsubscript¯𝒰superscript𝑏′𝑘𝑒subscript𝛼superscript𝑢′∇subscript~𝑓superscript𝑢′𝐰2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\sum\nolimits_{b=0}^{B-1}\alpha_{b}\Big{\|}\!\!\sum_{u\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}}\!\!\!\!\!\!\alpha_{u}\nabla\tilde{f}_{u}(\mathbf{w})-\sum\nolimits_{b^{\prime}=0}^{B-1}\alpha_{b^{\prime}}\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\sum_{u^{\prime}\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b^{\prime}}^{k,e}}\!\!\!\!\!\!\alpha_{u^{\prime}}\nabla\tilde{f}_{u^{\prime}}(\mathbf{w})\Big{\|}^{2}\leq\epsilon_{1}^{2},}

    where ∇f~u​(𝐰)≔∑l=0Luk,e−1∇fu​(𝐰)≔∇subscript~𝑓𝑢𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑙0superscriptsubscriptL𝑢𝑘𝑒1∇subscript𝑓𝑢𝐰\nabla\tilde{f}_{u}(\mathbf{w})\coloneqq\sum_{l=0}^{\mathrm{L}_{u}^{k,e}-1}\nabla f_{u}(\mathbf{w}).

Remark 1.

In (1), the first term captures the changes in the global loss function in consecutive rounds. The following terms with σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} come from the variance of the gradients. Besides, the following terms with ϵ02superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02\epsilon_{0}^{2} and ϵ12superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12\epsilon_{1}^{2} stem from the bounded divergence assumptions of the loss functions. Finally, the last term appears from the wireless links between the UEs and the BSs. Moreover, when the accumulated gradients are received successfully, i.e., all pu,sck,e=1superscriptsubscriptp𝑢sc𝑘𝑒1\mathrm{p}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e}=1, the last term becomes 00.

IV RawHFL: Joint Problem Formulation and Solutions

Theorem 1, Corollary 1 and Remark 1 show that the controllable terms in the convergence bound are the ΩksuperscriptΩ𝑘\Omega^{k}’s and the pu,sck,esuperscriptsubscriptp𝑢sc𝑘𝑒\mathrm{p}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e}’s. Besides, pu,sck,esuperscriptsubscriptp𝑢sc𝑘𝑒\mathrm{p}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e}’s are intertwined with the FL parameters (Luk,esuperscriptsubscriptL𝑢𝑘𝑒\mathrm{L}_{u}^{k,e}’s and fuk,esuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑢𝑘𝑒f_{u}^{k,e}’s) and wireless factors that influence (12). Furthermore, we assume that the accumulated gradients g~uk,esuperscriptsubscript~g𝑢𝑘𝑒\tilde{\mathrm{g}}_{u}^{k,e} is transmitted as a single wireless packet. The BS can successfully decode the gradients without errors555This assumption is reasonable as wireless networks use hybrid automatic repeat request and error correction mechanisms [16, Chap. 131313]. if it receives the packet within the deadline tthsubscripttth\mathrm{t_{th}}. As such, we denote pu,sck,e=Pr{[tu,cpk,e+tu,upk,e≤tth}\mathrm{p}_{u,\mathrm{sc}}^{k,e}=\mathrm{Pr}\{[\mathrm{t}_{u,\mathrm{cp}}^{k,e}+\mathrm{t}_{u,\mathrm{up}}^{k,e}\leq\mathrm{t_{th}}\}. The above facts inspire us to solve the following optimization problem to jointly select the clients and find their CPU frequencies and local iterations at the beginning of each edge round e𝑒e.

min𝟏slk,e,𝐋k,e,𝒇k,e1∑b=0B−1αb​∑u∈𝒰b1u,slk,e⋅[αu​Luk,e]superscriptsubscript1sl𝑘𝑒superscript𝐋𝑘𝑒superscript𝒇𝑘𝑒min1superscriptsubscript𝑏0𝐵1subscript𝛼𝑏subscript𝑢subscript𝒰𝑏⋅superscriptsubscript1𝑢sl𝑘𝑒delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑢superscriptsubscriptL𝑢𝑘𝑒\displaystyle\underset{\boldsymbol{\mathrm{1}}_{\mathrm{sl}}^{k,e},\boldsymbol{\mathrm{L}}^{k,e},\boldsymbol{f}^{k,e}}{\mathrm{min}}\quad\frac{1}{\sum_{b=0}^{B-1}\!\!\alpha_{b}\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{b}}\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sl}}^{k,e}\cdot[\alpha_{u}\mathrm{L}_{u}^{k,e}]} (19)
s.t.C1:1u,slk,e∈{0,1},∀u,k,e\displaystyle\mathrm{s.t.}\quad C_{1}:\quad\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sl}}^{k,e}\in\{0,1\},\quad\forall u,k,e (19a)
C2:∑u∈𝒰b1u,slk,e=Z,∀b,k,e\displaystyle\quad C_{2}:\quad\sum\nolimits_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{b}}\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sl}}^{k,e}=Z,\quad\forall b,k,e (19b)

C4:fuk,e≤fu,max,∀u,k,e\displaystyle\quad C_{4}:\quad f_{u}^{k,e}\leq f_{u,\mathrm{max}},\quad\forall u,k,e (19d)
C5:1u,slk,e⋅[tu,cpk,e+tu,upk,e]≤1u,slk,e⋅tth,∀u,k,e\displaystyle\quad C_{5}:\quad\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sl}}^{k,e}\cdot[\mathrm{t}_{u,\mathrm{cp}}^{k,e}+\mathrm{t}_{u,\mathrm{up}}^{k,e}]\leq\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sl}}^{k,e}\cdot\mathrm{t_{th}},\quad\forall u,k,e (19e)

where C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} are constraints for the client selection. Constraints C3subscript𝐶3C_{3} and C4subscript𝐶4C_{4} ensure that the client selects its local iteration and CPU frequency within the upper bounds. Besides, C5subscript𝐶5C_{5} and C6subscript𝐶6C_{6} are enforced to satisfy the deadline and energy constraints.

Note that we assume the clients share their system information with their associated BS. The BSs cooperate and solve (19) centrally. Then, each BS conveys the optimized parameters to their selected clients. It is also worth noting that we may equivalently minimize −∑b=0B−1αb​∑u∈𝒰b1u,slk,e⋅[αu​Luk,e]superscriptsubscript𝑏0𝐵1subscript𝛼𝑏subscript𝑢subscript𝒰𝑏⋅superscriptsubscript1𝑢sl𝑘𝑒delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑢superscriptsubscriptL𝑢𝑘𝑒-\sum\nolimits_{b=0}^{B-1}\alpha_{b}\sum\nolimits_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{b}}\mathrm{1}_{u,\mathrm{sl}}^{k,e}\cdot[\alpha_{u}\mathrm{L}_{u}^{k,e}]. Intuitively, this objective function should select the clients to optimize the weighted combination of their Luk,esuperscriptsubscriptL𝑢𝑘𝑒\mathrm{L}_{u}^{k,e}’s. However, both (19) and this equivalent objective function do not guarantee energy efficiency. Besides, based on our dataset acquisition and content request model, it is reasonable to consider tthsubscripttth\mathrm{t_{th}} is at least as long as the duration of the video content. Therefore, we seek an energy-efficient solution and consider the following weighted combination of the Luk,esuperscriptsubscriptL𝑢𝑘𝑒\mathrm{L}_{u}^{k,e}’s and energy expense of the clients as our objective function.

Note that problem (28) belongs to the class of “difference of convex programming” problems and can be solved iteratively using existing tools such as CVX [17]. Our proposed iterative solution is summarized in Algorithm 2.

V Simulation Results and Discussions

V-A Simulation Setting

To show the effectiveness of the proposed approach, we present simulation results from a system with the following settings. We consider B=4𝐵4B=4 and U=48𝑈48U=48. The coverage radius of the BS is 400400400 meters and each BS has |𝒰b|=12subscript𝒰𝑏12|\mathcal{U}_{b}|=12 UEs. Besides, G=8𝐺8G=8, C¯=32¯𝐶32\bar{C}=32, C=256𝐶256C=256, K=300𝐾300K=300, E=4𝐸4E=4, L=50L50\mathrm{L}=50, n=10n10\mathrm{n}=10, n¯=32¯n32\bar{\mathrm{n}}=32, ϕ=32italic-ϕ32\phi=32 [15], ζ=2×10−28𝜁2superscript1028\zeta=2\times 10^{-28}[14], I=50𝐼50I=50, ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1, θ=0.4𝜃0.4\theta=0.4 and κ=tth=150𝜅subscripttth150\kappa=\mathrm{t_{th}}=150 seconds. The activity levels pu,acsubscript𝑝𝑢acp_{u,\mathrm{ac}}’s and probability of requesting similar content from the same genre υusubscript𝜐𝑢\upsilon_{u}’s are drawn uniformly randomly from [0.2,0.8]0.20.8[0.2,0.8] and [0.1,0.8]0.10.8[0.1,0.8], respectively. The genre preferences pu,gsubscript𝑝𝑢𝑔p_{u,g}’s are generated using Dir​(0.3)Dir0.3\mathrm{Dir}(\boldsymbol{0.3}) distribution. The cusubscript𝑐𝑢c_{u}’s, fu,maxsubscript𝑓𝑢maxf_{u,\mathrm{max}}’s, eu,bdsubscripte𝑢bd\mathrm{e}_{u,\mathrm{bd}}’s and Pu,txsubscript𝑃𝑢tx{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}P_{u,\mathrm{tx}}}’s are randomly drawn from [25,40]2540[25,40] cycles, [1.2,2.0]1.22.0[1.2,2.0] GHz, [0.8,1.5]0.81.5[0.8,1.5] Joules and [20,30]2030[20,30] dBm, respectively. Furthermore, ω=3×180𝜔3180\omega=3\times 180 kHz and carrier frequency is 2.42.42.4 GHz. The path losses and line-of-sight probabilities are modeled based on the urban macro model as listed in [18, Section 7.47.47.4]. Moreover, we have used a fully connected (FC) neural network666Our solution is general and can easily be extended to accommodate other neural networks, such as recurrent neural networks or transformers. that has the following architecture: FC​(input​_​shape,512)→FC​(512,256)→FC​(256,output​_​shape)→FCinput_shape512FC512256→FC256output_shape\mathrm{FC}(\mathrm{input\_shape},512)\rightarrow\mathrm{FC}(512,256)\rightarrow\mathrm{FC}(256,\mathrm{output\_shape}). Finally, the clients use a sliding window technique, where, in slot t𝑡t, each UE processes its dataset so that the feature vector is the previously requested content’s information and the label is the currently requested content’s label.

V-B Performance Analysis

We first observe the convergence performance of the proposed algorithm with respect to different |𝒰¯bk,e|superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}|’s in Fig. 3. Intuitively, when the selected client set’s size is small, the global model is trained on fewer data samples. Under severe data heterogeneity, this may lead to poor performance if the clients are not selected appropriately. Besides, based on the objective function in (IV), the proposed solution proactively selects the clients that minimize the weighted utility function. Therefore, it is expected that RawHFL may take more global rounds to convergence when the |𝒰¯bk,e|superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}| is small. Our simulation results also show similar trends in Fig. 3. We observe that the test loss and test accuracy performances improve when |𝒰¯bk,e|superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}| increases. For example, with |𝒰¯bk,e|=2superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒2|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}|=2, the test accuracy drops about 3%percent33\% when K𝐾K is around 294294294, while the test accuracy reaches a plateau when K𝐾K is about 175175175 with |𝒰¯bk,e|=4superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒4|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}|=4.

However, while a larger |𝒰¯bk,e|superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}| may help RawHFL convergence faster, the bandwidth and energy costs also increase. More specifically, when |𝒰¯bk,e|superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}| increases, (28) must choose the defined number of clients so that the utility function is minimized. As such, it may select some clients with higher energy expenses. Our simulation results also validate this intuition. Fig. 3 shows the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the total energy expenses during each edge round e𝑒e for different client set sizes. For example, the clients spend no more than 0.180.180.18 Joules of energy about 76%percent7676\%, 52%percent5252\%, 37%percent3737\% and 29%percent2929\% of the edge rounds, when |𝒰¯bk,e|=2superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒2|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}|=2, |𝒰¯bk,e|=4superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒4|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}|=4, |𝒰¯bk,e|=6superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒6|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}|=6 and |𝒰¯bk,e|=8superscriptsubscript¯𝒰𝑏𝑘𝑒8|\bar{\mathcal{U}}_{b}^{k,e}|=8, respectively.

V-C Performance Comparisons

We next show performance comparisons with some baselines. To our best knowledge, no existing baseline exactly considers our system design and uses HFL for video caching. As such, we modify the traditional hierarchical federated averaging (H-FedAvg) algorithm [14] for comparison. In the modification, termed H-FedAvg-M111, we find the smallest number of local rounds that all clients can train their local models without violating their constraints. In the second modification, termed H-FedAvg-M222, we drop the straggler who cannot even perform a single local round and find the least number of local iterations that the rest of the remaining clients can perform without violating their constraints. In the third modification, termed H-FedAvg-UB, we consider the upper bound of H-FedAvg [14], where each client can perform LL\mathrm{L} local rounds without constraints. We assume Z=|𝒰b|𝑍subscript𝒰𝑏Z=|\mathcal{U}_{b}| for these baselines. Finally, we consider a naive popularity-based Top-Popular baseline.

In Fig. 3, we show the Top-M accuracy comparison of our proposed solution with these baselines. While a higher value of M should increase the accuracy, the baselines in constrained cases are expected to perform worse. Since all clients perform the same number of local rounds in H-FedAvg-M111, some ES may fail to train the model in some edge rounds as some clients may not have sufficient battery powers to offload their trained models due to poor channel conditions. H-FedAvg-M222 should work better than H-FedAvg-M111 as we drop these stragglers in H-FedAvg-M222. Besides, H-FedAvg-UB is the ideal case upper bound. Furthermore, since the clients request content following a popularity-preference tradeoff, the Top-Popular baseline is expected to perform worse. Our simulation results in Fig. 3, where the horizontal and the vertical lines show the mean and standard deviation of the test accuracies across all 484848 clients, also validate these trends. Particularly, our solution yields about 41.5%percent41.541.5\%, 31.7%percent31.731.7\% and 43.5%percent43.543.5\% higher (Top-111) test accuracies than H-FedAvg-M111, H-FedAvg-M222 and Top-Popular baselines, respectively. While RawHFL achieves nearly identical test accuracies compared to the H-FedAvg-UB baseline, our solution is energy efficient. We list the energy expenses of these baselines in Table II, which clearly indicates that our proposed solution outperforms these baselines.

VI Conclusion

We proposed a privacy-preserving RawHFL solution for video caching under a realistic content request model and real-time data sensing mechanism. Based on our convergence analysis and content request model, we optimized client selections, local training rounds and CPU frequencies jointly to minimize a weighted utility function that facilitated faster convergence energy-efficiently. Moreover, our results suggest a tradeoff between the number of participating clients that facilitates faster convergence and the corresponding resource expenses.
